item.title: Pairing: Pendragon/Merlin by anonymous (PG-13)
item.description:
Arthur is a BNF and Merlin is his prized beta. (~24,500 words) -- Arthur closed the window. Fuck. Mer.lin was good, amazing, really, so good, but had been right in their self-assessment. Merlin wasn’t a sycophant, and wasn’t nice about how they said things; Merlin just said them. It was…novel. And Arthur was fighting that little voice inside that was saying “oh my god, just smash your computer, ok?”, because some of the crit felt a bit like a punch to the gut.
[First posted here: http://community.livejournal.com/kinkme_merlin/19042.html?thread=18360162#t18360162 ]
item.dc:subject: fanfiction meta!fic fandom:Merlin humor romance epistolary writer modern_day kinkmeme Pairing:Arthur/Merlin Pairing:Gwen/Lancelot author:anonymous rating:pg-13 wc:020001-030000

item.title: News Desk: Why Is Eric Schmidt Stepping Down at Google? : The New Yorker
item.description: "Was Eric Schmidt pushed or did he jump? Both. According to close advisors, the Google C.E.O. was upset a year ago when co-founder Larry Page sided with his founding partner, Sergey Brin, to withdraw censored searches from China. Schmidt did not hide his belief that Google should stay in the world’s largest consumer marketplace. It was an indication of the nature of the relationship Schmidt had with the founders that he—as Brian Cashman of the Yankees did this week—acknowledged that the decision was made above his head. He often joked that he provided “adult supervision,” and was never shy about interrupting the founders at meetings to crystallize a point."

item.title: ACE - Ajax.org Code Editor
Sony v. Hotz: Sony Sends A Dangerous Message to Researchers -- and Its Customers | Electronic Frontier Foundation
item.description: Not content with the DMCA hammer, Sony is also bringing a slew of outrageous Computer Fraud and Abuse Act claims. The basic gist of Sony's argument is that the researchers accessed their own PlayStation 3 consoles in a way that violated the agreement that Sony imposes on users of its network (and supposedly enabled others to do the same). But the researchers don't seem to have used Sony's network in their research — they just used the consoles they bought with their own money. Simply put, Sony claims that it's illegal for users to access their own computers in a way that Sony doesn't like. Moreover, because the CFAA has criminal as well as civil penalties, Sony is actually saying that it's a crime for users to access their own computers in a way that Sony doesn't like.
item.dc:subject: cfaa hacking sony dmca jailbreak eff georgehotz

item.title: irvinebrown » Music for Shuffle
item.description: "I set myself a half-day project to write music specifically for shuffle mode – making use of randomness to try and make something more than the sum of its parts... Over an hour or so, I wrote a series of short, interlocking phrases (each formatted as an individual MP3) that can be played in any order and still (sort of) make musical sense." This is brilliant, and I do like Matt's ear.
